news_header: Sydney's Botanic Gardens attracted nearly 20,000 visitors to see the blooming of the endangered 'corpse flower', which emits a foul odor to attract pollinators.
news_text: The 'corpse flower', known as Putricia, bloomed at Sydney's Botanic Gardens, drawing almost 20,000 visitors. This endangered plant, native to Sumatra, emits a putrid smell for 24 hours after blooming to attract pollinators. It blooms only every 7-10 years in the wild, with fewer than 1,000 plants globally. Other news includes Julian Assange's release in Australia, a winter solstice event in Hobart, and a tragic stabbing incident in Bondi Junction.
